newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thai stocks end weaker on profit-taking, politics.
newsitem.headline: Thai stocks end weaker on profit-taking, politics.

text.p: Thai stocks ended lower in thin trade on Thursday as some investors took profits and uncertainty over the future of the government kept others on the sidelines, brokers said.
The SET index ended 4.32 points down at 1.090.71 on slim 2.7 billion baht trade. Decliners beat gainers 202 to 105 with 116 unchanged. The SET-50 index was 0.32 points off at 82.23
"We saw a bit of profit taking after the sharp rise yesterday on foreign specualtive buying and politics is still keeping many investors away," said a local analyst.

Politics has cast gloom over the jittery bourse since last week when one of the partners in Prime Minister Banharn Silpa-archa's seven-party coalition quit. Earlier this week the opposition filed a censure motion against Banharn for debate on September 11, compounding the unease.
Japanese funds entered the market on Wendesday hoping to ride a wave of buying as the first portion of a 21 billion baht local support fund was invested.
But brokers said the low volume on Thursday showed that foreigners had again retreated and the local support fund was not actively trying to push the market higher.
"The support fund just cushions the market when it declines," said an analyst at Adkinson Securities.
The finance sector ended 1.14 percent lower on 590 million baht and the bank sector finished 0.68 percent off on 493 million baht turnover.
Bangkok Bank was most active, two baht down at 210. Thai Farmers Bank gained one to 173 and Finance One lost two to 108.
